text: ON a housing project in the industrial outskirts of Bosto BANGING seems to flutter away, leading us along, searchin tiny balcony, one of dozens, ten stories up.  And there, of the sound -- -- A SHEET, snapping in the wind.  The umbrella-like clot on which it hangs bangs against a dirty glass door as if get in. THROUGH THE GLASS DOOR a woman paces inside, agitated.  T rise over the banging, becoming intelligible --
-- becoming a fight.
, 30s, dark-haired, furious, wheels across a diminutive, neat, but poor living room.

It'll take a month to probate the will, Nell!  A month!  Even if Mother left you something, you won't get it in time to pay the rent.  So instead of complaining, you should be thanking Lou for getting you these two weeks to get Mother's things packed.
At first we can't even see who she's yelling at.  At firs even notice her.  Then we do... Holding herself, in a dim corner away from the light, sma like a part of the faded room is
, 20's -- Nell. She stares at the door.  The clothes line raps at the beg glass. JANE (cont'd) Nell?
The wind dies, the banging stops.  Nell seems to hear Jan peers over at her, then across the room to Jane's bored h
.  He's turning a Franklin Mint commemorative coin set in hands, studying it.
You're still going to have to settle with your mother's landlord  on the back rent.
Nell watches Jane's little boy,
.  Unpacified by the  cartoons on the TV, he plows a plastic tank across a shel neat rows of delicate PORCELAIN DOLLS.
I'm not going to stay.  I'll get a  job.  I'll get my own apartment.
Richie knocks a porcelain DOLL off, and it breaks all ove carpet.  His parents don't notice.  But Nell feels it in Richie stops.  A long beat.  He looks at her, insolent, t on with his tank.
Nell.  A job?  Two months and where is this job?  You have no degree, you've never worked --
Nell explodes in outraged fury, startling us.
-- I've never worked? --
You have no experience in the world... the regular world.  What  would you put on a resume? (beat, softening) Now we all appreciate what you did  for Mother.  Isn't that right,  Lou?
Eleven years.  Long time.

That's why we've been talking. With me getting more time in Accessories, and Lou at the shop  all day, we need somebody to take  care of Richie, do a little  cleaning and cooking.  And in  return you can have the extra  room.

She goes to Lou, puts a hand on his shoulder, proud of he generosity.  All Nell can do is stare. And then: KNOCK KNOCK.  Like a shot Nell is out of the ch turning for a set of FRENCH DOORS across the room.  It's reflex.  Nell catches herself. KNOCK KNOCK.  Richie, lying on the couch like he's sick, the wall with a wooden CANE and squeals:
Eleanor, help me!  I've got to  pee!
Nell REACTS, but rather than being amused or annoyed, a w TRAUMA flickers over her face.  The reaction is so strong instantly know something is very wrong.
Richie, knock it off before I beat  the crap out of you!
Nell turns away, sick, breathing hard. Jane picks up a JEWELRY BOX from a dresser.

You're sure this is all of  Mother's jewelry?  The lawyer said  to make sure we took it to him... (beat) He said there might be some  antique pieces.  Have you seen anything?  Some of it might be valuable.

Nell knows what is going to happen to that jewelry.  Jane can bear the weight of Nell's stare, checks her watch.  S Lou.  Lou rises, pocketing the coin set.  Richie follows JANE (cont'd) Think about our offer, Nell.  You  don't know how hard it is out  there.

Nell rams through the door into the small kitchen, spotle And then bursts into tears.  Shaking, she digs in her bac and pulls out a FINE FILIGREE NECKLACE.  Her mother's.  I an age gone by. Clutching the necklace, she goes back out the door.
Nell crosses the living room straight for the closed Fren the glass obscured by gauze curtains.  She throws them op enters --

-- what once was a dining room.  Transformed into a sick Drawn shades.  Dim.  The first traces of dust. Nell lingers in the doorway a beat, daunted. A perfectly made bed.  The PILLOW, however retains the IM of a head.  Lodged between the bed and a nightstand, a CA the opposite side of the bed is a plastic toilet.  I.V. s Shrouded white shapes. On the wall above the bed, a framed needlepoint counsels: FOR EVERYTHING, EVERYTHING IN ITS PLACE.  A bit of wisdom to live a life. A way Nell has lived for too long.  Seeing it galvanizes movement.  She goes to an old armoire, a medicine chest, removes a BOTTLE OF TYLENOL WITH CODEINE and marches out.
Nell closes the doors on the chamber of horrors, exhales. been holding her breath.

Nell sits at her tiny kitchen table, water glass and Tyle front of her.  The necklace dangles from her fingers.  Sh mesmerized by it.  Then she undoes the hasp.  The clothes outside BATTERS louder -- -- and, defiant, Nell puts the necklace on.  She closes h Silence.  The battering has stopped.  A BEAT.  And then t RINGS.  Nell opens her eyes.  The phone RINGS.  Keeps rin Nell, feeling the drug, finds her way to the phone and pi
Hello?  Yes, this is Eleanor. -- Where?  Yes, it's right here.
Nell listens for a long moment.  She picks up the classif flips through.  And there it is:

head_text.subj: OLD HOUSE IN BERKSHIRES. PSYCHOLOGY STUDY.

text: The lab feels more like the video center of a security of a psychologist's laboratory.  Two banks of black and whit give us images of men and women, different ages, differen wired to electrodes.  They are taking psychological tests we never see the Testers.  The subjects are working throu variations on object manipulation and pattern recognition There are subtle differences between the two banks of mon the left, the subjects are all twitching at exactly the s on the right, the subjects are also twitching, but in no  discernible sequence.  The subjects on the left are bette concentrate on their tasks.  The subjects on the right ke stopping, and going over what they have done. Two men,
, in his 50's, is a graying professor, the  head of the department; someone we trust. He faces

.  He is a man whose confidence  rests uneasily on his ambition, and in the tension betwee is the power that makes him the teacher students love.  R though, he is defending himself before a Department Revie is not a court martial with judges behind a desk, it's mo form. The men are having a fight, and they are watched by OTHER PROFESSORS.
It's still an electric shock!
Come on Malcolm, it's only seven ohms, it's nothing, it's like a joy buzzer!  And it's not about the pain, it's about the interference with concentration...

Malcolm looks at the monitor.  This is Marrow's chance to it again. MARROW (cont'd) Look, look at what it does!  The  subjects on the left, because they  anticipate the shocks, make the  adjustment, and lose nothing on  their scores.  The subjects on the  right, because the shocks are  random, can't anticipate, and the  distraction throws them off.

Stop defending your science after  the fact, Jim.  The department  protocol for research is very  clear about this, and you violated  the rules.  I know, I know, I know  that "Fear and Performance" is a  big sexy idea, but as long as I'm  chairman here you will need this  department's endorsement to  publish it, and right now I can't  do that.
At this moment,

, late 20's, Marrow's pretty T.A.,  opens the door with an armload of files.  Whatever else s wearing, she wears glasses.  Marrow, seeing her, motions go away.  He doesn't break eye contact with Malcolm.  Mar hesitates...

Malcolm, this is essential work  I'm doing.  Just think what my  research can do for education.   Elementary school classrooms near  train tracks or airports, where  loud noise is random; this helps  to prove the need for sound  insulation if the children are  ever going to learn to read.
And that will be a good place to  end this study.

No, Malcolm!  Individual  performance is only part of it.  I  know why baseball players choke  for no reason, I know why  violinists throw up with fear  before every concert, and need to,  to give a great performance, but  what I want to know is, how fear  works in a group...
Not the way you've constructed  your group, it's just not ethical!
But if the group knows it's being  studied as a group, you  contaminate the results.  The  deception is minor.
Malcolm sees Mary Lambretta.
Are you working with her?
Mary, I'll meet you outside.
She understands, and she closes the door.
Why are you working with her?   Mary Lambretta was thrown out of  the department for trying to get a  Ph.D. in psychic studies.
And after she was thrown out, she  needed a job.
You don't believe in the  paranormal.
No, but she does, and that's all  that matters.
Does she know that's why you're  using her?
No.
I, I just can't...
She needed a job, Malcolm.  And  she's smart.  And she helps me.
I have a bad feeling about what  you're doing.
This is the last chapter.  Please,  please give me clearance.  It's  for science.
Marrow waits.
I'm gonna hate myself for this.
But he nods.  Permission granted.
Thank you.
They open the door.  They walk out.  Mary is there.  She eyes, and does a gypsy voice.
I see a hostile man... he's (she  describes him).  The hostile man  does not believe in Madame Velka.
This relieves the pressure.  Malcolm is not listening any storms off.
You know what he's really upset  about?
What?
You're going to publish, he's  going to perish... And why did you  hire me for this?
Marrow has a sly smile.  They go into his office through door in the lab.
Long, narrow, badly lit, it's filled with filing cabinets of unread textbooks still in publisher's plastic, a desk computer.  As soon as they enter, Mary looks at the phone
It's for you.
And then the phone rings.  He doesn't pick it right up, h ring.
You hear the vibrations in the  wire.  There's a magnetic pulse in  the wires, you feel it.  I could  test it.
Test it.
The phone still rings.  Marrow answers.
Yes, this is Doctor Marrow.
How'd I know it was for you?
(quickly) Because it's my phone. (back to the phone) Yes... Mrs. Dudley, just leave the  boxes inside, thank you.  See you  soon.  Thank you.
He hangs up. Marrow is trying to read the first file as he goes to his Mary shows him a huge CORKBOARD covered with photos, arti various items.

Here's how they're organized.   Groups of five, very different  personalities: scored all over the  Kiersey Temperament Sorter just  like you asked for.  And they all  score high on the insomnia charts.
Good.
A PHOTO OF NELL falls on the floor.  Marrow scoops it up. the photo of Nell up to Mary, and look at the written not studies the graphs that go with it. MARROW (cont'd) This is correct?
Her mother died two months ago.   She says she really wants to do  this.  I didn't know if it'd be  taking advantage...
Marrow considers the lonely image for a long moment and t at the graph of her test scores.
(meaning the graph, not the face) What a beautiful profile.  How do  you feel about her?  What does  your
intuition say? Mary balks at his teasing.
I put my favorites on the top.
Marrow continues to study the files.
Okay... this one's good...  Extrovert Feeler... Okay... This  one I like, too...

We don't pay as much attention now to the cork board as t images on the wall.  We find clinical-looking shots from Milgram's experiments: subjects appearing to scream in re electrical shock. Rows of weeping prisoners in the Stanford prison experime Photos of victims crushed under the stands of a soccer st aftermath of a riot.  A picture of the Fuhrer before his masses.  Mary opens a large envelope.  She takes out a ph that we can't see.
What's this? (has to get his attention) What's this... this picture?
That?  That's Hill House.
This is where we're going?
Yes.  It's perfect, isn't it?
Mary studies the picture, and she can't answer him.  In h glasses, we get the thinnest reflection of the photograph glimpse of dark brick and high chimneys.
Nell, in a rust-wormed old Buick, glances from the road t computer-drawn DIRECTIONS TO HILL HOUSE.  She HUMS A TUNE lonely, like a lullaby but eerie, off-key.
The car speeds down the country road, past old stone wall into rolling meadow, its winding route taking it across t Berkshires, farther and farther into the glorious hills.

Countryside speeds by.  She passes an antique store in a handpainted sign warns MELBY'S APPLE FARM 100 YARDS.  Nel for the window handle, letting in air. She snorts, smelling, breathing like it was the first tim life... sounding like a pig.  And it makes her burst out embarrassing, animal laughter.
The white-steepled church, five stores and gas station of lie in a forgotten notch in the hills.

Nell is pumping gas at a country station.  She is alone a pump.  As she finishes, she hears a BABY CRYING.  She loo She is immediately drawn by the sound. She moves to a car at another pump.  The car is empty.  T are rolled up.  She peers into the car, through the windo sees a toddler in a car seat.  The child is crying.  Nell around, no one is there.  She makes faces at the baby, co
Hello Baby...
She does a peek-a-boo game, and the baby stops crying, th even starts to giggle. A VOICE from behind.
What's going on, what happened?
Nell turns.  The Mother is a busy country mom, arms fille stuff from the gas station's market.
She's okay.  She woke up and she  saw she was alone.
The mother has the car open and the baby is smiling now.
Say thank you, Spencer. (too much of an explanation) I was getting her something to  drink.  She's been crying all  day...
That's all right.
Of course you know, how many  children do you have?
None.
Then you're a teacher.  Nursery  school.
No.
You just... you seem like someone  who takes care of children, lots  of children.
Maybe... maybe someday.  I'd like  that.
The woman smiles in something like sympathy, and gets in When she does, we see a friendly GAS STATION ATTENDANT ap behind Nell. NELL (cont'd) Umm, I'm a little lost.
Where you going?
Nell takes out her computer drawn directions and an old m
They sent me directions and I've  got a map, but it's kind of  confusing.  Here... it's a place  called Hill House?
His helpful attitude changes dramatically.
Hill House.
He takes the map book and tears out the page and crumples
What are you doing?
You don't want to go there.
He turns abruptly and walks away.
Did I say something wrong to you?
Nell slams the Buick door, and breathing hard, starts the She gets control, and puts the car in gear.  She's shaken
Nell's Buick bounces over a country road.  The car works into the steep, switchbacking hills.
Nell looks out at the forest, feels a chill.  The road is a tunnel through the forest than a road.
Nell's car speeds through the trees, climbing the hills, higher into the awesome solitude.

Nell takes a final switchback, and something off to the r catches her eye, then is gone in the trees.  She watches it.  There.  A glimpse of a gray stone property wall set twenty yards from the road. There it is again.  Moss-greened, twenty feet high, a wic of iron spikes and glass mortared atop it. And then out of the tangled forest in front of her looms immense stone pillars.  Between them, a steel GATE as hig wall, chained and padlocked.

The gate stands immense.  Silent.  Forbidding.  Beyond th gravel drive curves away through the trees.  Nell kills h gets out, instructions in hand.  No one in sight.  A long She reaches in and blows the HORN. The HORN shatters the air, rackets off the trees beyond t echoing.  Silence. Nell blows the HORN a sustained staccato in annoyance.  T replies in a terrible, deafening battering of sound.  Nel her ears.  Silence once again. In a fit of agitation she goes to the padlock and rattles locked good.  She turns -- -- and there is a man right behind her.  It is
, his hair tied back like an ex-hippie.  He stands between Nell and car door, weed spear in hand.  He smiles at her -- rough, massive.
What do you want?
Oh!  You scared me.
Me?  No.  What are you doing here?
Are you Mister Dudley, the caretaker?
Yeah, I'm Mister Dudley, the  caretaker.  What are you doing  here?
I'm with Dr. Marrow's group.  I'm  supposed to check in with Mrs.  Dudley up at the house.  Is she  here?
She hands him the directions.  He glances at them.  She u distraction to get into her car.
Maybe she is...
Nell looks at the gate, some part of her aware it's a poi return.  Mr. Dudley eases over to her window.  Mr. Dudley one last look and goes to the gate.  He produces a keyrin undoes the padlock.
Why do you need a chain like that?
That's a good question.  What is  it about fences?  Sometimes a  locked chain makes people on both  sides of the fence just a little  more comfortable.  Why would that  be?
He unwinds the enormous chain, heavy turn after heavy tur gates swing in, revealing HILL HOUSE.
Is there something about the  house?
Mrs. Dudley'll be waiting for you.

Grinning, Dudley steps aside and Nell rolls through.  And he just grins wider.  Nell pulls away.  Disturbed, she wa in the rearview mirror.  She turns and in front of her sp House.  At center, the features of the oldest part of the dwarf all others: towering, eye-like windows and the jaws Grand Entry with carved ebony doors.
The car rumbles up the drive toward the carport.
Nell stops the car in front of the entrance, right inside carport.  In the silence all we can hear is her breathing

Her car sits in front of the house, tiny, alone.  Its bra go off. The finger-like pillars of the car port seem like a hand the car in place under the House's gaze. Nell gets out of the car. Nell stares, daunted... yet there is something about the romance in its lilac heavy Gothic decay.  Nell feels it, to it.

Nell, suitcase in hand, climbs the steps to the front doo closer inspection, the snaking shapes of the carved doors Garden of Eden.  At center on the knocker, a tarnished si takes the forbidden fruit from his counterpart Eve. Nell lifts Adam and knocks heavily.  There is no answer. looks around for some sign of life. Off to one side is a LADDER and PAINT CANS.  Somebody mus touching up the window trim. When she looks back the door is AJAR a fraction of an inc
Hello?  Hello?  Mrs. Dudley?  Mrs.  Dudley, are you here?  Anybody?
Tentative, she pushes it open into --

-- a vast entry towering away to a ceiling lost in shadow above.  Rays of light filter through floor-to-ceiling cur Doors lead off in a half dozen directions. Every piece of woodwork or plaster in the house is carved filigreed, painted or ornamented in wild, ornate fashion. overwhelms the eye.
Wow...

She turns around, sets her suitcase on the marble floor. hallway straight ahead seems to let onto some vast space, lit. And then Nell hears a SOUND.  Carrying through the empty some distant place: a low, plaintive MOAN. Nell freezes.  The MOANING stops.  Nell strains her ears. the MOAN again.  It comes from the short hallway ahead. starts for it.  The Moan stops.

location: HALL FROM ENTRY TO GREAT HALL

text: Nell moves down the hall.  It's dim, stale, lined with pi candelabra.
Hello?  Hello?  Mrs. Dudley?
Her voice echoes from the room beyond.  She follows her o into --

-- A long, oval great hall.  Passages and doors lead off directions to God-knows-where.  A double-grand staircase end ascends to a landing shrouded in darkness before turn next floor.  Magnificent ANIMAL HEADS carved on the newel glare at her. Nell makes her way past clusters of furniture, stops at t Silence.  An ENORMOUS FIREPLACE dominates one wall.  Larg to stand in.  An iron mesh SCREEN hangs in its mouth.  Ma chimney rise in dark, baroque masonry, becoming lost in t above. The MOANING sound.  Nell spins away from the fireplace. rises from the door at the very back of the hall.  Nell t step toward it.
Mrs. Dudley?
She moves up to the door, puts a hand out to it.  The MOA rises. Nell pushes through --
-- into a much narrower, curving hallway.  Doors all alon sound comes from the door right there across from the one came through.  She flings it open --

-- and comes through into a vast kitchen.  A woman in bla her back to Nell stands at a counter.  The moaning comes disreputable old CAN OPENER. Nell breaths, feels stupid.  The woman senses her, turns cans of potatoes.  She is
, sallow, unsmiling.
It's make the soup or answer the  door.  Can't do both.
Mrs. Dudley.
So far.
Mrs. Dudley wipes her hands, regards Nell, nods.
I'm Eleanor Vance, I'm with --
-- Dr. Marrow's group.  You're the  first.
Mrs. Dudley just stares with her sunken face.  It unsettl MRS. DUDLEY (cont'd) I'll show you your room.

Mrs. Dudley glides up the stairs.  Nell follows, hoisting suitcase after her.  It appears the mezzanine ahead leads hallway.  But as we draw closer what we thought was a hal ENORMOUS OIL PAINTING.  In it stands a man, his features the shadows above, only his body visible. The nameplate reads HUGH CRAIN.
Hugh Crain.
Nell looks up: Mrs. Dudley waits coldly at the top of the
Mrs. Dudley leads Nell down a curved hallway, over aged P carpets and turns to a door on her left.  She throws it o stands back.  Nell enters.
Nell lowers her suitcase.
The Purple Room.  You're going to  be the first visitors that Hill  House has had since Mister Crain  died.

The room is spacious, in a rococo gothic style with low-r woodwork on the walls rising to a dark, coffered, ceiling ivory.  A king-size bed, furniture, all in blue purple. door gives a glimpse of a bathroom. A large fireplace dominates one wall.  Its mantle is carv the faces of children, happy, at play, alive.  Nell touch wood, loving.
They're so beautiful.  Aren't  they?
I've seen 'em.  Lot to dust.
Well, I've never lived with  beauty.  You must love working  here.
Mrs. Dudley peers at her.  A beat.  And then, cryptic:

It's a job.  I keep banker's  hours.  I set dinner on the dining  room sideboard at six.  You can  serve yourselves.  Breakfast is  ready at nine.  I don't wait on  people.  I don't stay after  dinner.  Not after it begins to  get dark.  I leave before dark  comes.  We live in town.  Nine  miles.  So there won't be anyone  around if you need help.  We  couldn't even hear you, in the  night.
Why would we --
-- no one could.  No one lives any  nearer than town.  No one will  come any nearer than that.  In the  night.  In the dark.

And with that Mrs. Dudley grins, rictus-like.  She turns the door after her. Nell stands there a long moment, the room silent, heavy, goes to the windows, peers out.  Nothing but forest for m The sun is setting . Nell removes her windbreaker, opens her suitcase, takes o blouse and skirt.  Decent enough clothes, but cheap, the on them.

Nell emerges from her room in her new clothes.  The hallw away into the distance, lined with massive, ornate doorfr the one to her room. Trying to get a better look, Nell searches the walls for switch, but can't find one.  She follows the chair rail b

-- the mezzanine at the top of the stairs.  She searches for a light switch there.  Finally she spots a set of cur slings them open. The light, late-day though it is, makes her wince.  The w looks down on the driveway.  Outside a BEIGE CAR crunches gravel.  Somebody else has arrived. Nell watches the car move past, trying to get a glimpse o driver, but from up here, all she can see is roof.
Finally.

She backs away from the window, spins around -- -- and out of the darkness, powerful, mad, looms the visa Crain.  It is the painting.  It is only from up here on t floor with this curtain open that the FACE is visible in day sunlight. Despite the artist's discretion, the lines in the man's s eyes, his posture, cry of unspeakable sickness. Unconsciously, Nell takes a step back.  In the far b.g., end of one of the halls, a DOOR stands open, the second o set of doors in the Gothic Hallway left of the painting. it starts to come into view, and we're starting to see it swings silently shut. But Nell has caught the movement out of the corner of her
Nell stares down the long hallway.  Which door was it?
Hello?

No response.  She starts down the hall, slow at first, th She passes door after door, shadow after shadow, and as s the end of the hall... there is no door here.  Not within of, where we thought we just saw it. A WHISPER.  VOICES.  Nell backs away.  And then LAUGHTER. her.  It's coming from another stairwell.  Very real... a human.
Nell looks down from the top of the stairs.  Below Mrs. D
, 20s, exotic, sophisticated, in Vera Wang leather, wrest a pile of designer luggage.  Theo peers up.  She's dark, amused, worldly way: someone who has seen and done it all
You may think I have a sickness  about packing, but asking people  to help me shlep the stuff I take  with me everywhere is a cheap and  exploitative way of making new  friends.  My name's Theo.
Theo foists a very heavy bag off on Mrs. Dudley who looks been handed a snake.  That makes Nell smile.  She comes r to help with the bags.
I'm Eleanor but everyone calls me  Nell.  Eleanor Vance.  Nell.  I'm  really glad you're here.  Really.
Theo is a little thrown by Nell's gushing. NELL (cont'd) What a beautiful jacket.
Theo looks her over... and understands.  Nell is desperat liked.
And what you're wearing, that's  great, too.
This?  It's from a thrift shop.
What did it cost?
Fifteen dollars.
That'd be seventy in New York.   You stole it!
(embarrassed by the  simple truth) It's all I could afford.
Wait.  You're not wearing that  ironically?  This is really you?
I don't know what you mean.
Mrs. Dudley, walking ahead, looks back at them.  Then con Theo makes a face at Mrs. Dudley's back.  Nell smiles, a
A week.  You and I?  We're going  to have fun.
Mrs. Dudley opens the door, letting Theo and Nell into a bedroom, a mirror-image twin of Nell's room, except it's in rich red-orange velvets.
This is so twisted.
She dumps her stuff on the floor, grabs a banister on the poster bed, swings cat-like onto its high mattress.
I set dinner on the dining room  sideboard at six.
Mrs. Dudley lays Theo's suitcase on a luggage stand.
Breakfast is at nine.  I don't  stay after dinner.  Not after it  begins to get dark.
Theo, back to Mrs.  Dudley, rolls her eyes at Nell. MRS. DUDLEY (cont'd) I leave, before dark.  So there  won't be anyone around if you need  help.
We couldn't even hear you.
Mrs. Dudley looks up at Nell who mimics her scary smile.
No one could.  No one lives any  nearer than town.
No one will come any nearer than  that.
Mrs. Dudley smiles at Nell, but it's softer than before.
In the night.  In the dark.
Theo leans on the bed, musing at the exchange.  And then backs out of the room, shuts the door. NELL (cont'd) My room is right next door.  I  think we share a bathroom.
Theo has an interesting eye on Nell, she's studying her.
Don't worry, I probably won't be  in here much.  Light sleeper.
That's why we're here.
What do you do?
I'm between jobs right now.  My  last job... it... the person I was  working for... the job ended.   Over.  So... And you?
That depends.

Theo pops a dress bag on the bed, unzips it.  Theo takes coat, and is only wearing a black bra underneath.  Nell r turns away.  Back to the camera, Theo flicks off her bra, THEO (cont'd) I'm supposed to be an artist, but  I've been really distracted from  work by love.  Do you know what I  mean?
Not really.
Don't tell me Boston is different  from New York.
(she knows this  from magazines) Ohh, sure, you have trouble with commitment.

My boyfriend thinks so, my  girlfriend doesn't.  If we could  all live together... but... they  hate each other.  It's hard to be  Miss Perversity when you're the  only one at the party.  D'you know  what I mean?
No.
(delighted) A blank canvas!  I could paint  your portrait, directly on you.   Or maybe not.  So, you?  Husbands?   Boyfriends?  Girlfriends?  Where  do you live?

I don't have anyone. (beat, lying) But I do have a little apartment  of my own.  It has a little flower  garden.  You can just see the  ocean.  At night, when the wind  comes in just right, you can hear  the buoys in the harbor.
Nell peeks, sees Theo is decent, turns around.
That sounds really nice.  You're  lucky.  But you know that.

Nell, in a plush chair, lays t a table beside her.  The CLATTER of stone on stone makes up. The fireplace looms just beyond her cluster of chairs, la for a man to stand in.  A piece of mortar must have come Nell stares at the chimney.  And a VOICE lets out a loud Nell JUMPS.  She pops out of the chair.  It came from ano of furniture in the shadows.  A figure stands and comes o Luke, stretching. LUKE (cont'd) I've been thinking about these  carvings.  Kids.  Lots of kids.   Fat little angel kids.  Wild kids.   Kids with furry animals.
The children.  The children Hugh  Crain built the house for.  The  children he never had.
Come on.  These are the typically  sentimental gestures of a depraved  industrialist.

He puts his hand on a CHAIR, the back of which is heavily the motif he just described. Nell turns him an appalled look. LUKE (cont'd) Theo was working in the dining  room.  She's probably done by now.   You finish?
Couldn't get the last ones.  You?
I did okay.

Nell looks at the test, tries to digest this. LUKE (cont'd) We could do this stuff anywhere.   I don't know what he's up to yet.   But like I said, that's the fun.   It has something to do with this  environment.

Luke just smiles, rises.  We'll see. He walks off, his footsteps echoing in the vast room.  Th shuts after him. Nell sags in her chair.  Then something catches her eye. opposite, a SET OF KEYS.  Nell goes, picks them up.  Car keys.  Must be Luke's.  She pockets them, thoughtful, but she does -- -- something MOVES in the fireplace.  So fleeting Nell ca see it, and we only catch a frame of it.  But the iron ME hanging in front of the hearth is STILL SWAYING. Nell stands there FROZEN.  The massive fireplace LOOMS be like a monstrous mouth, black as pitch beyond the black m curtains. The swaying metal scrapes over brick floor.  Its eerie, r screep cutting to the nerve. Nell sits paralyzed, rooted to the chair.  SCREEP.  SCREE A SINGLE STRAND of NELL'S HAIR stirs toward the fireplace

head_text.subj: -- SOMETHING INSIDE THE FIREPLACE MOVES BEHIND THE MESH

text: Nell CRASHES back over her chair, knocking over a lamp an tripping, stumbling out of the furniture. Holy shit.  Whatever moved in there was real.  Big, dark, something's head.  It goes out of focus and we can't see follow -- -- NELL flying away, across the room in headlong terror.

Nell slams out of the room, skidding as the door slams be She sways up off the floor to run -- -- right into Marrow and Theo's legs.  Nell aborts a scre realizing who it is.  Theo stands there in surprise, hold in her hand.
There's someone in there!  There's  someone in there in the fireplace!

Nell and Theo stand behind Marrow and Luke across from th fireplace.  Theo glances at Nell.  Nell is shaken. Marrow nods to Luke, and they start forward together, Mar the furniture to the left, Luke down the right side. The iron screens hang silent in the fireplace, black, imp Marrow and Luke come up on either side, Luke ducking this that trying to get a glimpse through the mesh. They stop before it, neither breathing, both listening. steps forward and pulls one screen aside far enough to lo DARKNESS. Nell and Theo watch, apprehensive.
Jim...
Marrow sticks his head into the fireplace.  For a long mo nothing happens. IN THE FIREPLACE: pitch darkness.  Marrow feels up the ch

head_text.subj: AND THEN SOMETHING SWINGS DOWN RIGHT IN FRONT OF HIS FACE

text: doesn't flinch. He FLINGS back the screen, revealing the only things in t fireplace: two massive andirons, and the still-swinging F cast-iron, forged in the shape of a LION'S HEAD. Luke throws back the other screen.  Theo comes over.  Nel There's nothing else in the fireplace. Luke and Theo stare at Nell.  Marrow squats to study the The large iron ASH-DROP is coated in soot. Not a mark on it.  He opens it.  Inside, a glimpse of ASH CHARRED WOOD.  Marrow stands, looks at Nell. NELL (cont'd) Somebody was in here.  I saw him.

Marrow looks at her, not sure what to believe.  Nell turn and Theo for help.  Not from that corner.  Then Nell reme reaches into her pocket and produces the KEYS.  She holds Luke. NELL (cont'd) Are these yours?  I found them  right over there.
Who drives a Toyota?
Theo shakes her head.  They aren't Marrow's.  Marrow take from Nell, turns them over.
Maybe they're Mary's.
Mary came with me.
When I first got here I saw a gray  car pull up.  I thought it was one  of us.
They stand on the front steps.  Nell's car is right there car port.
This is my car.
Theo gestures to a sports car on the circular drive.  Two are with it.  They walk out into the driveway.
And those are Luke's and mine.
There's a carriage house around  back.
Together they approach a stable/carriage house off to one the main House.  It looks old, unused.  They enter throug door.

Light filters in through gaps in the wood.  Luke opens on main doors with a loud SQUEAK, the sun revealing a TARP-C SHAPE, a carriage.  Unused in a hundred years.  A row of covered carriages fill the stalls into the distance.
Well, this lot is full!
He must have left.  Didn't like  the looks of the place or  something.
How could he have left without his  keys?
Two sets.  I don't know.  Maybe  they're not even his.
Then he's got to be in the  house...
As they leave, the CAMERA LINGERS on a covered shape in o stalls, SMALLER than the other carriages, it could be a c broken wagon wheel leaning against it.
Marrow, Theo and Luke move down the hall, opening doors l right as Nell stands at the center of it all.
Watts!
No answer.  The statuary peers down on Nell.  Dead faces Blind marble eyes.
Luke calls out.
Watts!  Oh Watts!  Here Wattsy...
Marrow is looking for him, too.
Watts!  Can you hear us?
Nell and Theo, walking into rooms.
Watts?
What's his first name?
David.
David?  David Watts?  Can you hear  us?  David!  Daviiiiid!
Marrow comes through the kitchen.  Mrs. Dudley, chopping stands by the counter.  Only the slightest pause in the r her chopping says she's noticed him.
Do you know who these keys belong  to?
No.
I was expecting another guest  yesterday.  A man, David Watts.   Did you see him?
No.
Is your husband around?  I'd like  to --
-- Haven't seen him.
Thank you.
Frustrated, he continues on.
Nell and Theo walk down the long hallway behind, opening checking rooms.
David?
Maybe he never came in.  If he'd  come in, he would have left his  bags at the door, right?  Or maybe  he got here early, and went for a  walk, and fell.  Maybe he's  outside.

Nell closes a door on the right, and then stops dead.  St The shut, dark, door, the one that scared Nell and Theo e awaits them at the end.  Ominous. Nell approaches.  Closer and closer.  The door nears. Nell wraps her arms tightly about herself and try's to op door.  It's locked.  Her BREATH FOGS THE AIR.  She doesn' it.  But then she suddenly GAGS.  With a look of horror s from the door, choking, covering her face. Then Theo smells it.  The women are both sick from the sm THEO (cont'd) Oh my God, what is it?  Oh, the  smell... ohhh.
Marrow comes into the hallway.  He sees them from a dista ON the two women.
(looks to Nell for  an answer) Is it over?
No, it's getting worse.
Nell!  What's wrong?
That smell... oh, God.
Theo blanches, looks at Nell.  She smells it too, and in image fashion backs away from the doors also.  Marrow not exchange, and watches them, intense.  And then, in a hear moment is over.
The RED LIGHT on Marrow's DIGITAL VOICE RECORDER blinks. is in Marrow's jacket pocket, CONCEALED from Nell.  They' in Adirondack chairs on the long veranda behind the House beside her, observes.
What did it smell like?
It was very specific.
(so tell me...) All right...
In the bathroom in my mother's  room, the toilet was next to an  old wooden table.  It smelled like  that wood.
So... smell... is... Smell is the  sense that triggers the most  powerful memories.  And a memory  can trigger a smell.
I wasn't thinking about my  mother's bathroom.
What happened after you smelled  it?
I looked at Theo.  She had a look  on her face.
Like she smelled it too?
Yes.
And then what happened?
I got more scared.
Marrow thinks about this.
Hmm.
I'm sorry.  I'm messing up the  study.
No you're not.  Something moved  you.  You saw something.
Nell looks to him.  He's sincere.  He believes her.
I don't know.  Maybe I...
"Didn't" she almost says.  She struggles, embarrassed. NELL (cont'd) I haven't been with people in a  long time.
Marrow settles in his chair, looks out at the forest.
I really haven't either.

Nell peers at him, doubtful.  Is she being made fun of? MARROW (cont'd) I mean, I'm surrounded by people,  day in, dayout.  Students,  colleagues. (beat) But most of the time, even when  I'm with them... you know... It's  all about power, there's not much  room for actually getting to know  someone or having someone getting  to know you.

Nell's face flushes with compassion.  With longing.  Marr her.  He's vulnerable.  Needing.  She doesn't dare hope. lasts a few heartbeats. He looks away.  A flicker of distress crosses Nell's face she realizes Marrow is looking at -- -- Luke. LUKE (cont'd) You have to see something.

Luke, Nell and Marrow mount the stairs, climb up and up. Theo in the mezzanine staring at the wall at the painting turns and looks at Nell strangely. Nell, confused, turns around.  On the wall and the painti stains.  Black.  Blue.  Runny.  Almost like something lea the roof has run down. Nell steps back.  The stains are the letters N and O.  Pu farther: the rest of the word ELEANOR.
My name.
She follows the streaking substance up, blinking in risin more running letters appear.  The word: WELCOME.  And hig last: HOME. NELL (cont'd) No...

But the substance doesn't come from the ceiling. It is as if the oils on the PAINTING OF HUGH CRAIN have b by a heat gun and blasted off, running down from there. is gone.  In place of the face, the underlying ivory of t glares out... like a skull. Nell SCREAMS and runs away, the others calling out after alarm.  As they vanish around the corner, the camera tilt we discover smeared paint on the floor.  Smeared, it seem LITTLE FOOTPRINTS in it.
Nell, panic rising in her voice, confronts the others.
Welcome Home Eleanor.  Welcome  Home?  I've never been here.  Who  did this?
It's somebody's idea of a joke.
She looks at all three of them.
Who did this?  Why are you doing  this?  I don't know any of you.   You don't know me.  Why are you  doing this to me?
Luke shakes his head.  Theo starts getting pissed.  Marro there, arms folded, observing.
I didn't do it.
You could have.
So could you!  Is this some fucked  up idea of art, putting someone  else's name to a painting?
No.
Theo... Did you?
Maybe you did it yourself.
Why?
I don't know.  You've been alone  for a long time, maybe you want  attention. (pointing to  Marrow) Maybe he did it...
I didn't.  You know that, Nell.
This is horrifying to Nell, being doubted and accused of so ugly if it were true.
I don't know anything.  Whoever  did this, please, just... just say  so... just... please... this is  cruel.  Don't be cruel to me.  I  can't stand it.  You don't know  me.
And she runs out. Nell grabs for the door to leave. She flings open the door.  MONSTROUS arms seem to grab at it's only a wild-looking coat rack in the hall.

Nell stands at the railing of a stone balcony on the hous floor.  The air stirs her hair.  She peers up at the Hous roofline, its clusters of misplaced windows and other fea so many screaming heads. Chilled, she pulls her sweater closer.  Marrow comes out balcony from twin French doors behind her.
Are you coming to confess?

I wish I were.  I wish I had done  it, then I could confess and you'd  be at peace.  That great moral  philosopher Frank Sinatra once  said to someone he loved, I wish  you had an enemy, so I could beat  him up.
She smiles.
Let's say it wasn't you.  Who did  it?
I don't know.
It was a stupid thing to do.
It was.
(for the absurdity  of the idea) Welcome Home.
You'll never see it again.  Mr.  Dudley's taking care of it. (beat) I'm sorry, Nell.  Can I show you  something you'd like to see?
(still too shaky  for enthusiasm) Sure.

Marrow lets Nell into a long, Victorian-era GREENHOUSE. overgrown, lush, the leaded-glass panes above stained wit condensation and pollen.  Vines and trees climb up the si of flowers and plants line narrow footpaths of brick. Nell leans down to look into a WATER GARDEN with a STATUE bursting from the surface, grasping for the air as if he drowning.  A sudden rumble runs throughout the greenhouse CAVALCADE of water comes out of the STATUE'S mouth surpri She lets out a little yelp, and then laughs with Marrow. Nell loves the greenhouse.  It takes her breath away.
Oh... it's so beautiful...

Nell makes her way among the plants.  She looks up at a T DOUBLE-HELIX STAIRCASE which rises from the floor to a pl which gives access to the roof.  Below the staircase are filled with violets. NELL (cont'd) Violets.  Somebody must've died  here.
And then, out of the corners, comes Mister Dudley.
That's where she hanged herself.
Who?
Rene Crain.  Up there.  Rope.   Ship's hawser.  Hard to tie.   Don't know how she got it.
That's enough, Mister Dudley.
She stepped off the platform. (he looks up, with  a suggestive leer) They had long skirts in those  days.
Thank you, Mister Dudley,  please...
House is full of stories.  If you  know how to read these things,  it's an open book.  Just a  different library than the kind  you're used to.
Why?
Why'd she kill herself?
Yes.
(what other reason  is there?) She was unhappy.
Why?
Can't say.  Haven't been here that  long. (he's off) Well, it's Labor Day, gotta get to  work.
And off he goes.
That's a horrible story.
Nell looks up, and smiles. MARROW (cont'd) You're smiling.
Marrow watches her as she moves about, takes a heavy, rip hand, lifts it to her face.  While she talks, she walks, follows.

I was just thinking how happy I am  right now.  All my life, I've been  waiting for an adventure.  And I  thought, oh, I'll never have that,  adventures are for people who  travel long distances, that's for  soldiers, that's for the women  that the bullfighters fall in love  with.  And here I am, and  something is happening to me.   Strange noises in the night.   Paintings are calling to me.  And  all it cost to get there was five  gallons of gas.  I'm getting my  adventure.

For the first time since we've seen Nell, there is someth which is simply... erotic.  Marrow follows her down one o footpaths.  She smiles back at Marrow as he trails her. a transept in the greenhouse, and as she turns down it, t slightest sway to her gait.  Marrow follows her around th into the transept.  At the far end the wall is completely Nell looks up through the ceiling at Hill House looming g outside, distorted in the old glass.
Someone is playing with you.
Why?
I don't know.
It doesn't matter.  Even if  they're tormenting me, someone  wants me.  What I do with this is  up to me.  I can be a victim, or I  can be a volunteer.  And I want to  be the volunteer.

Nell glances at him, and for that split second she is raw passionate woman.  She walks away, the sway in her gait a powerful.  Marrow is surprised by what Nell just said and her as she comes to the overgrown end.  Nell reaches out hanging vines, pulls them aside... ...and A FACE stares out.  Gastly.  White.  Nell takes an involuntary step back, a little gasp. The face is marble.  Blind eyes stare from stained cheeks STATUE OF CRAIN.  Marrow comes over. It's an enormous stone tableaux of Hugh surrounded by che plants have attacked it as if trying to wipe its funerary from the greenhouse. NELL (cont'd) Hugh Crain.  Can't seem to get  away from him.

She laughs a little at herself.  Marrow joins in.  He hel the plants back to reveal more of it. She reaches out, touches the marble cheek.  Then daring, begins to hum her TUNE. Marrow steps back to watch her do a sensual slow-dance wi Crain, pirouetting, her hips sliding past... hypnotizing
What is that tune?
I don't know.  A lullaby I guess.   My mother used to hum it to me.   And her mother before that, and so  on. (to the statue) Hugh Crain, would you care to  dance?

She hums another two notes, and BANG!  The door behind he OPEN in a gust of wind, jolting Nell.  She stops and star Outside the window, through the glass, she sees Mr. Dudle at her, he's been watching her dance.  The spell is broke embarrassed, can't bear to look at him. A beat, and then Marrow goes over and shuts the door.  Wh back -- -- Nell is just vanishing around the corner, her rapid fo echoing in the vaulted room.

Nell hurries away from the House, across the rear lawn, a herself as much as she is spooked. In the distance Mr. Dudley is walking toward the House wi paint cleaner an a ladder.  Nell stops, watching him.  He her, pauses, and smiles. Nell reacts.  Sees the ladder.  Then Mr. Dudley disappear House. Nell once again starts to hurry away, but looking back ov shoulder, almost impales herself on the rusted iron fence

-- the tiny Crain family cemetery.  Nell catches herself. swinging gate bars the way.  She hesitates. Nine moss-covered headstones show the wear of a long cent small headstones, one large one.  A half dozen unmarked s the grass: stillbirths. Nell is drawn into the graveyard.  The large stone is REN The smaller ones are her children's. Nell's heart is breaking as she moves among them: the var One reads ADAM CRAIN APRIL 5th 1874 -- ... The rest of th covered by growth.  She clears it away.  April 6th, 1874.
Only two days.
There is an EPITAPH, almost wiped out by lichens.  Nell k read it. NELL (cont'd) The blest are the dead / Who see  not the sight / Of their own  desolation...

Nell, disturbed but not knowing what to make of it, rises gravestone, turns to the next.  ELISA CRAIN AUGUST 21ST, clears it away: August 21, 1878.  The blasphemous epitaph NELL (cont'd) A father's joy unjustly snatch'd  by a jealous God...

Nell is shaken, and dreading what she will find next, whi one behind her: WENDY CRAIN JANUARY 1 , 1880 -- She clear -- January 1, 1880.  And its graven commandment, so famil comforting, now rings with terrible, malevolent promise: NELL (cont'd) Suffer the little children unto  me.

There are three more grave stones, and after clearing awa brush, they too show that the babies died after a few hou day.  There's the same symbol on the graves of the childr cherub of death.  We've seen this image before.  Nell bac the cemetery, afraid.
Nell hurries down the mezzanine to the doorway which lead Red Parlor.

She stands there a beat staring in at the volumes upon vo books.  Nell is unsure of what she's looking for.  She lo Crain's painting and recognizes the same Cherubs inside t frame.  The background in the painting IS THE RED PARLOR. recognizes in the painting an OPEN BOOKCASE BEHIND CRAIN. Intuitively, she turns toward the same bookcase across fr is able to push it open.  Inside a small stairwell...

Down the circular stairs Nell enters a very small dusty r Velvet curtains drawn shut, only a sliver of sunlight sho through.  As her eyes adjust, she makes out the furnishin late-nineteenth century office, Crain's secret office. The bookcases filled with business ledgers.  The business are stamped with the cherub of death. At the end is an enormous desk.  Behind it a massive, car covered with a sheet, only its lion-head arm rests protru underneath.  Nell realizes it's:
Crain's study.

She moves for the desk.  An ENORMOUS MIRROR, its silver i surface flaking with age, tarnished, reflects the room, t and FOR A SPLIT SECOND, A SHADOW IN THE CHAIR.  Nell step of it, blocking our view. And when she steps past, there is only the dim, flaking i chair, the natural shadow of the room. Nell goes around the desk, stands over it.  The chair sit behind her, shrouded. On the desk sits a set of ledgers marked with mill names Haverhill, Manchester -- and years: 1884, '85 and so on. one open. THE LEDGER is a payroll account.  Names upon names of wor rendered in sepia by Crain's severe cursive.  Notations i column beside it indicate man, woman, or child and the ap wage for each class of worker.  Many of them, at least a children. NELL reacts.  Disturbed by it.  She shifts closer to that behind her.  The sheet hangs over it in such a way that s could be sitting there under it. She turns the page.  Columns indicate pay, and so on.  Bu column, at the very center of the book, hidden in the bin unlabeled. Down the column, some names have a line drawn them, and at the end of the line, a CROSS. Nell follows them back, eyes searching across the ledger. She turns the page, pushes the book down revealing that c column, more crosses.  And more.  Her eyes flick back and The crosses are paired with entries for CHILD.  She looks names... NELL (cont'd) Erin, Peter and Sean and Emily and  Elizabeth... who are you?  And  you?  What happened to you?  You  died... How did you die?
Nell turns the pages.  More and more crosses.  Dozens.  S Nell sinks down into Crain's chair and tears come to her see the book.
The painting is right there now.  The letters have been e
We see the ledger, and pull back, and the ledger is in Ne Nell sits on the bed in her sleeping tee-shirt and undies looks at the book with her.
That's so sad.
There's hundreds of them.  This  must be a record of the children  who died at the mills, like Luke  said.
Before he painted your name over  Mister Crain.
Theo hands her the bottle.  Nell takes it, tops off her g spilling.  Her face is red.  She grimaces as she tosses b swallow.
You really think it was Luke?
Theo takes another swig.  She holds bottles of nail polis to Nell's bare feet, testing the colors.

Well, it wasn't me.  Mister Dudley  had to clean it and he knows that  he's in charge of all the messes  so why would he make more work for  himself and... (beat) You said the Good Doctor was with  you.
(pondering) I don't know what to think  anymore.
Just think about one thing right  now: What color?
Nell finally puts the book down and takes a drink.
I've never had a pedicure before.
Well?
Red. (into this now) What else?
Theo smiles and takes Nell's foot gently in her hand.  Sh paint her toenails. THEO (cont'd) See, isn't this better than a hit  on the head?
Nell looks down her long legs at Theo.
I'm sorry I was mad at you, Theo.
Me too.  Although I learned one  thing about you, that you don't  know about yourself.  You can be a  pretty decent bitch.
Nell shoots down the rest of the glass of wine.
I'll take that as a compliment. (beat, trying to  sound casual) In the city, what kind of place do  you live in?
I have a loft.
Nell is thrilled with this.
A loft.  That's a lot of room for  one person.  Probably.  Maybe  there's room for...
Theo looks up, understands what she's asking.
You want to move to New York, you  want to move in with me?
I don't know, you know...

Nell lies back, arms spread, lets the glass roll out of h Theo paints Nell's toenails one by one, carefully guiding strokes in along the skin.  Nell, unused to this, gives i pleasure, and Theo sees how easy it is to move Nell.

My place isn't like yours, Nell,  it doesn't have a view of sea.  It  doesn't have a view of anything.   What's interesting about the way I  live is what goes on inside the  walls.  Living with me... My  boundaries aren't very well  defined, Nell.  Do you know what I  mean?
I'm trying.  Have you ever kept  something to yourself because you  were afraid it'd ruin things.
Theo looks up at her, unreadable.
All the time.

Nell lets out a sigh.  Gently Theo's hand moves down the Nell's foot.  Caressing.  Nell lets her. Theo finishes Nell's last little toe, and then with the b paint, runs it gently up the inside of Nell's calf.  Nell Theo lowers her face near Nell's toes, licks her lips: so red.  She blows. Nell raises herself up, peers down at Theo.  Sees the wan face.  A long beat. Nell breaks the gaze, looks away.  Theo reads Nell's look releases her foot.  She sits back in the chair.  For a mo doesn't know what to do. NELL (cont'd) I better go to bed.
Are you sure?
I think so.
Okay.

Nell closes the door and sits at the vanity brushing out for bed.  Her motions are languid in the light of the sin lamp, off-balance with the wine. Her HAIR brushes out in long, even strokes.  The brush mo it, lifting it and letting it fall. IN THE MIRROR the brush draws through Nell's hair, but as the hair divides in its wake LIKE FINGERS RUNNING THROUGH Nell freezes.  She's not sure what she just saw.  She run through again, and again it is as if something pulls it b her head. Again -- fast -- she runs the brush through her hair, and the hair SPINS UP IN A KNOT. Nell flinches, dropping the brush, knocking the shade of the vanity a-wobbling. She's out of the chair in a flash, grabbing her own hair, the space behind her.  Nothing there.  A beat. She steadies herself, feeling the alcohol.  Gets control. The Tiffany lamp rocks back and forth, crystal beads shim The light plays across the fireplace and mantle on the wa something there catches her eye. Nell feels her way across the room, not sure of what she' Over the sound of the wind outside, there's something at highest edge of hearing. She stops five feet from the mantle.  The swaying light c rich tones of wood.  Then darkens.  Illuminates it again. The carvings of the playing CHILDREN in the wood SEEM TO Nell stares in drunken fascination.  And as the first fea rise in her throat, the wind dies down and in its place t FAINTEST TRACE OF CHILDREN'S LAUGHTER.  Nell's reaction c to awe. Tentative, her hand goes out, shaking... and touches the It is hard and still.  No movement whatsoever.  Silence. FACES engraved in the wood all seem to be peering up at h outstretched for her, hopeful.
The enormous LOCKED gates are silhouetted against the moo The chain is dangling in the wind.
Hold on Nell's WINDOW, the light shining dim through the curtain.  It goes out.  The window stares from an arrange other windows, stonework and doors... like an eye with a a face howling in horror.

Nell, her breathing heavy, lies tangled in her heavy blan asleep, but restless.  Her feet hang off the end of the b In the b.g., the door to the bathroom is shut, barely vis faint light from the window.  HOLD on it. Silently, it begins to OPEN.  The gap WIDENS, yawning, pi beyond.  A long beat.  And then a THUMP.  A SLIDING SOUND Something drags itself across the floor. BUMP.  SLIDE.  Our line of sight is blocked by the bed. sound is getting louder, coming closer. Bump.  Slide.  Nell grinds her teeth in her sleep, pulls blankets about her tighter.  Bump.  The sound stops.  And BEGINS TO FOG. Whatever has just come in the room is right there, hoveri We can feel it. Without warning Nell BOLTS upright, GASPING into consciou REVEAL: nothing.  Just the dark room.  And the bathroom d Nell stares at the-door, knows she shut it.  Now it's ope breaths fast, feeling the cold, knowing something's in he her. She stops breathing, strains her ears.  Silence.  A long Then she notices her feet, hanging out from under the cov They are black.  Feel slick.  Nell turns on the light by looks down. HER FEET ARE COVERED IN GORE.  Where Theo had been painti SCREAMS.
SCREAMING, Nell spins the tub faucets on full blast, stic into the spray.
Nell?  Nell!
Weeping, Nell scrubs the gore off her feet -- red, black clotted blood.
Who is doing this to me?
The door to Theo's bedroom is shut.  The handle rattles, it won't open.  It's LOCKED.
Nell, what's wrong?  What's wrong?
The blood or whatever it is on Nell's feet comes off, is the drain. THEO (OC) (cont'd) Nell, it's locked, let me in!
Nell, squatting in the tub, sobs as her feet come clean, are NO WOUNDS.  Theo rattles the door.
Nell, the door is locked.  Open  it.

Nell rises, steps out of the tub, and looking like she co moves for Theo's door. She grabs the handle but realizes what Theo has been tryi her all along: it's LOCKED.  Perplexed, Nell finds the ke hole, and turns it. The door rams open, Theo behind it, terrified and clearly awoken. THEO (cont'd) Nell...

Nell stares at her, hair tangled, tear-stained, doubtful. splashes in the tub, faucets still running. The LIGHTS flicker as one in the connecting rooms.
